challenge.description: Preparation of an extremely thick electrode with high active material loading for neutron diffraction studies.
challenge.impact: High loading density is required to ensure sufficient material for neutron diffraction, but achieving this without compromising electrode performance is challenging.

solution.description: A novel methodology was developed using aluminum foam as a sacrificial template to produce a highly porous, thick electrode with a 3-dimensional conducting pathway.
solution.methodology: Utilized aluminum foam to create a porous structure while maintaining high active material loading (∼378 mg·cm−2).
solution.effectiveness: The electrode achieved ∼40 mAh·cm−2 areal capacity, which is almost an order of magnitude larger than commercial LIBs, demonstrating the success of the approach.

evidence.data: The electrode contained 0.33 g of LiMn2O4 powder with a loading density of ∼378 mg·cm−2, as shown in Figure 2.

context.material_properties: High porosity and 3-dimensional conducting pathways for electron transport.
context.experimental_conditions: Electrode thickness of ∼6.5 mm and use of aluminum foam as a template.
context.application_relevance: Critical for in operando neutron diffraction studies to monitor phase transitions during cycling.

challenge.description: Minimizing background noise in neutron diffraction data caused by hydrogen-rich components in the electrochemical cell.
challenge.impact: High background noise can obscure critical structural information about the material under study.

solution.description: Designed a neutron-compatible electrochemical cell using deuterated electrolytes and glass fiber separators to reduce hydrogen scattering.
solution.methodology: Replaced conventional components with deuterated EC/DMC electrolyte and glass fiber separators to minimize hydrogen content.
solution.effectiveness: The approach successfully reduced background noise, enabling clear observation of diffraction peaks from the active material.

evidence.data: Neutron diffraction patterns showed minimized unwanted peaks from the sample environment, as highlighted in Figure 3d, e.

context.material_properties: Sensitivity of neutron diffraction to light elements like lithium and oxygen.
context.experimental_conditions: Use of deuterated electrolyte (1.10 M LiPF6 in 31 wt% d-EC and 69 wt% d-DMC) and glass fiber separators.
context.application_relevance: Essential for accurate in operando neutron diffraction studies of lithium-ion battery materials.

challenge.description: Irreversible phase transition at the 2.7 V plateau due to Jahn-Teller distortion of Mn3+ in the tetragonal phase.
challenge.impact: The distortion causes anisotropic strain, leading to particle fracture and internal contact loss upon cycling, which degrades battery performance.

solution.description: Proposed a comprehensive understanding of reaction mechanisms involving solid-solution regions within both cubic and tetragonal phases.
solution.methodology: Used in operando neutron diffraction and first-principles calculations to identify intermediate metastable phases and their structural evolution.
solution.effectiveness: The findings redefined the conventional understanding of two-phase reactions and provided insights into mitigating structural degradation.

evidence.data: Observed continuous variation in Mn-O bond lengths during cycling, indicating the presence of solid-solution regions, as shown in Figures 5 and S8.

context.material_properties: Jahn-Teller distortion in Mn3+ leads to significant changes in axial ratio (c/a) from 1.0 to 1.6.
context.experimental_conditions: Cycling between 4.4 and 2.0 V with in operando neutron diffraction monitoring.
context.application_relevance: Understanding and mitigating phase transitions is critical for improving the cycling stability of lithium-ion batteries.
